headline: Poly students endorse Oyetola for second term
summarized_story:
The National Association of Polytechnic Students on Wednesday endorsed Osun State Governor, Adegboyega Oyetola, for another term.
According to a statement by the governor’s Chief Press Secretary, Ismail Omipidan, the students explained that they decided to support Oyetola in order to sustain the tempo of steady progress and development in the state.
The statement quoted the association’s National President, Olalere Benedict, as saying that the endorsement was aimed at reciprocating the governor’s good gesture towards the students in the state and Nigeria at large.
“This endorsement and honour bestowed on our leader and father for second term as Osun State governor are to seek for his support in remodelling and rebranding the association and students’ structure in the state to meet up with the demands of the polytechnic students across Nigeria,” he said.
Receiving the award on behalf of the governor, the deputy governor, Benedict Alabi, said the present administration holds students in high esteem and would always do everything to prioritise their interests.

headline: Police arrest hotelier over OAU Post-graduate student’s death
summarized_story:

Opalola said the hotelier was the latest suspect arrested in connection with the incident, adding that six people had earlier been arrested.

headline: PHOTOS: Group Chairman, UBA, Tony Elumelu visits Zambian President
summarized_story:

headline: PDP appoints Caretaker Committee for Lagos
summarized_story:
The National Working Committee (NWC) of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) has ki appointed Mr Julius Akinsola, as the Chairman of the Caretaker Committee of the Lagos State chapter of the party.
The PDP said this in a statement by its National Organising Secretary, retired Col. Austin Akobundu on Wednesday in Abuja.
Akobundu said that the decision of the NWC was pursuant to its powers under Sections 29(2)(b) and 31(2)€ of the PDP Constitution (2017 as amended).
“The caretaker committee is charged with the responsibility of running the affairs of the party in Lagos State as stipulated in Section 21(2)(a-b) of the PDP Constitution, for a period, not exceeding 90 days (from November to February 2022) until a new executive committee is elected.
“All critical stakeholders, leaders and members of our great party in Lagos state and other parts of the country is by this guided accordingly,” Akobundu said.

headline: Military, police not rivals – Lagos CP Odumosu
summarized_story:
Commissioner of Police in Lagos State, Hakeem Odumosu says the military, police and other units are not rivals.

Odumosu noted that the visit will enable the course participants to get thorough knowledge of the strategies being adopted by the command.
“The strategies include, but not limited to, proactive and intelligence-driven security strategies against crimes and criminality to ensure a secured environment”, he disclosed.

headline: Gbajabiamila appoints ex-Rep, Adedapo Lam-Adesina as aide on political matters
summarized_story:
House of Representatives Speaker, Femi Gbajabiamila has appointed Adedapo Lam-Adesina as his Special Assistant on Political Matters (South-West).

headline: Kano, institute partner on animal feed production
summarized_story:
The Kano State Agro-Pastoral Development Project (KSADP) has signed an agreement with the Nigerian Institute of Animal Science (NIAS) for pasture production in the state.
Shortly after signing the agreement in Kano, the State Project Coordinator of KSADP Malam Ibrahim Garba Muhammad revealed that, as part of the agreement, the project has allocated four hectares of land to NIAS, at Kadawa, Garun Mallam Local Government Area, for pasture production.
The Registrar, who is the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Nigerian Institute of Animal Science, Prof. Eustace Ayemere Iyayi, said the endeavour would help in meeting the increasing demand for fodder.
Prof. Iyayi explained that the institute would use irrigation and rain-fed pasture production techniques to develop the four hectares it received.
Managing Director of Kano State Agricultural and Rural Development Agency’s (KSADP’s) executing agency, Dr Junaidu Yakubu Muhammad, promised that the state government would create the enabling environment for a mutually rewarding and sustainable partnership with the Nigerian Institute of Animal Science.

headline: Forum seeks probe of NSCDC boss
summarized_story:
The Unified Nigerian Youth Forum (UNYF) has called on President Muhammadu Buhari to investigate allegations of corruption against the Commandant-General of the Nigerian Security and Civil Defence Corps (NSCDC), Dr Ahmed Audi.

In less than a year of his headship, he has transferred many professional, patriotic, committed and brave commanders of the corps out of strategic position/commands and replaced them with his puppet, which lacks all the required professional qualities to occupy such sensitive positions.”UNFY said: “With the current insecurity which ranges from banditry, cattle rustling and all other forms of criminality, the NSCDC is expected to support the armed forces, the police and other security outfits in tackling crimes.”- Advertisement -The forum said should Mr President fail to act now, it will not hesitate to carry out massive protests across the country.

The signal originated from the Department of Finance and Administration in Enugu State and was addressed to all Assistant Commissioners of Police, Heads of Department and Divisional Police Officers in the state.

headline: Nigerians enrolment in US universities hits 3yr low
summarized_story:

Analysts attribute the decline to foreign exchange (FX) scarcity and difficulty in sourcing FX, thus making tuition fees expensive.
“It is not surprising because the difficulty in sourcing for FX, volatility in the exchange rate, and uncertainty that persists in the exchange rate environment have made it too difficult to pay school fees,” Moses Ojo, a Lagos-based economic analyst, says.
Before the drop, the number of Nigerian students studying in the US has increased steadily since the 2011/2012 academic year from 7,028 to 13,762 in 2019/20.
It is also facing the problem of dilapidated infrastructure,” Peter Okebukola, former executive secretary of the National Universities Commission, said.

headline: NRC directs shutdown of train services over warning strike
summarized_story:
The Nigerian Railway Corporation has ordered the suspension of train services between Abuja and Kaduna, Lagos, Ibadan, and Warri due to a strike.
The NRC directed district managers to be prepared to shut down train stations plying Abuja-Kaduna, Lagos-Ibadan and Warri-Itakpe routes in the event that workers down tools.
The three-day warning strike by workers of the Nigerian Railway Corporation (NRC) is to hold from November 18th to November 20th.
A letter titled, “Notice and Directive to embark on 3-day warning strike nationwide,” dated November 12th, had been addressed by the District Chairman/Secretary Nigeria Union of Railway workers and Senior Staff Association.
The mobilisation for the strike is unprecedented and the entire NRC workers are top gear for the warning strike,” he said.

headline: FG announces possible resumption of flights to UAE
summarized_story:
The federal government has announced the possibility of resuming flights between Nigeria and the United Arab Emirates (UAE).
National incident manager of the presidential steering group on COVID-19, Mukhtar Muhammad, said both countries had agreed on the UAE government’s revised travel limits and conditions.
He explained that, in order to maintain harmony, the federal government has agreed to the COVID-19 testing requirement imposed by the UAE government in March 2021.
Direct flights between both countries were suspended in March over issues relating to COVID-19 protocol.
In February, Emirates directed Nigerian travellers at the Lagos and Abuja airports to conduct rapid COVID-19 tests before departure, which led to a ban on Emirates flights in Nigeria.

headline: Obasanjo Seeks More Cross Border Trade within Africa
summarized_story:
On the third Day of the Intra-African Trade Fair in Durban, South Africa, ARISE News spoke exclusively to former Nigerian President and Chairman of the Intra-African Trade Forum Advisory Council, Olusegun Obasanjo.
He said there is a need for African countries to break free from colonial legacies which have kept countries from trusting and trading more with each other.

headline: “We Already Knew There Was a Massacre” – Falz on #EndSARS Panel Report on Lekki Shooting
summarized_story:
It was supposed to be a hub of peaceful dissent against police brutality, the symbol and the sum of the frustration and crushed hopes of Nigeria’s youth.
But the atmosphere changed dramatically when the country’s security forces opened fire on young protestors just over a year ago at the Lekki tollgate in Lagos.
The shooting was captured on mobile phones and live-streamed on Instagram, but the Nigerian authorities denied it had ever happened.
Well now the victims, the journalists and the activists who sought to prove that the security forces shot and killed #EndSARS protestors have been vindicated by the official report into the shooting, which called it a massacre.

headline: Delhi Smog: Schools and Colleges Shut as Pollution Worsens
summarized_story:
Authorities in the India capital, Delhi, have shut all schools and colleges indefinitely amid the worsening levels of air pollution.

headline: Nigeria’s Parliament Intervenes in Diplomatic Row with UAE
summarized_story:
